Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Role of the Substrate Surface State and Molecular Configuration in Porous Honeycomb Networks of Quinones
Award.AbstractNarration: The Analytical & Surface Chemistry Program of the Division of Chemistry, in the Directorate of Mathematical & Physical Sciences of the National Science Foundation, will support research by Theodore L. Einstein of the University of Maryland, College Park and Ludwig Bartels of the University of California, Riverside. The goal of this work is to understand how particular organic molecules assemble into large regular honeycomb patterns with open pores having diameters of 5 nm. To explore how general this behavior is, Bartels will perform experiments on different molecules and substrate materials in conjunction with theoretical calculations by Einstein that seek to explain the short-range structure in terms of hydrogen bonds and the large pores in terms of the electronic structure of the substrate. With a command of the interaction mechanisms, Bartels and Einstein will seek to engineer the size of open pores and perhaps also the pattern of the molecular networks. Such surfaces can serve as templates for growing patterned films on surfaces for applications ranging from storage technology to heterogeneous catalysis. Educational benefits include the training of graduate students and postdoctoral associates in state-of-the-art techniques for imaging at the atomic scale and for simulating systems in which comparatively small energies and subtle effects determine the overall geometry. It is also an outstanding opportunity for synergistic and close collaboration between physics-based theory and chemistry-based experiment, offering the involved students highly interdisciplinary training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Watching molecular motion in confinement

We follow at the atomic scale the motion of individual carbon monoxide molecules that are confined in the pores of a honeycomb mesh of anthraquinone molecules just on a copper surface.  Trapped inside the pores just a few nanometers across, we can study the carbon monoxides' mobility, their locations, and the way they assemble into a complete film. We find that they move much more rapidly inside the pore and their speed of motion increases further, if more molecules are present. The surface network confines not only molecular motion inside the pores but also the surface electrons of the underlying copper, thus generating quantized states analogous to atomic orbitals but in 2D rather than  3D. Solving the Schrödinger equation inside the pore, we find those states and observe that the molecules move exactly to the locations associated with them, conceptually like filling up electron levels in an atomic orbital diagram, but using molecules, which are readily observed.

At complete coverage the molecules do not assemble into a continuous film inside the pore; rather they form two films or domains, starting from opposite corners of the pore and offset a little, giving rise to a boundary between them that runs across the pore. We observe that this boundary persists; neither of the two half films ever covers the pore completely and the boundary constantly moves back and forth, strikingly different from films on extended surfaces, where such boundaries

How would a horse move if it were only 1 nm long?

In particular, would it trot, or pace, or simply glide across a surface? And would its hoofs need to be lifted over obstacles or can they quantum-mechanically tunnel through them? In an upcoming paper in the Journal of the American Chemical Society we investigate the motion of molecular species that are attached with four linkers to a metallic surface and compare it to species that have only two. These species are particular in as much as sequential movement of their linkers allows them to move in a straight line on a flat surface, preventing them from rotation or veering off course. For the quadrupedal kind of molecules we find that they move in a pacing gait always moving two hoofs on the same side of their body in unison. Thus, they behave very much like bipedal species which move one foot at a time. Investigation of the temperature-dependence of their speed highlights a fundamental difference between their motions. The oxygen feet of bipedal species are actually light enough to tunnel through corrugation of the substrate; their feet can move through rather than over obstacles on the ground. Species with heavier sulfur feet cannot do this. Also quadrupedal species, which in pacing move two feet at a time, do not employ tunneling because the concerted tunneling of two hoofs required for their motion is prohibitively less likely than the movement of a single foot.
